Overview.Summary: The 2014-2015 Greek presidential election (10) was held on December 17, 2014 (1, 9), two months earlier than scheduled (9). The election was a political gamble for Prime Minister Antonis Samaras (10) and was met with mixed reactions (4, 7, 8). The possibility of a bank run was a concern for the country (3), and the election was seen as a race against time (3). The outcome resulted in a defeat for the incumbent prime minister (2) and triggered a general election (6). The European Commission formally backed a candidate in the election (4).

Timeline.Text: Greek Prime Minister Antonis Samaras announces that the presidential election will be held on December 17.
The European Commission officially backs a candidate in the Greek presidential election and applauds the government's decision to hold snap elections.
The first round of the Greek presidential election takes place, with candidate Stavros Dimas receiving 160 votes.
The Greek government falls short in the first round of the presidential vote, increasing the likelihood of a snap election.
The Greek presidential election goes to a third round, with the possibility of a snap election looming.
Greek Prime Minister Antonis Samaras urges lawmakers to avoid a snap election.
The possibility of a bank run is identified as Greece's Achilles' heel in the presidential election.
Outgoing Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras concedes defeat in the presidential election.

Overview.Summary: The 2014-2015 Greek presidential election (9) saw Prokopis Pavlopoulos, the candidate of the government, elected as the new president of Greece with a wide majority (1). The election was called as a gamble to end political uncertainty (3) and was seen as a test for the restructuring of the Greek political system (4). The election process involved three rounds of voting in parliament (5,6). The unemployment rate in Greece was a key issue in the election (8). The nomination of Pavlopoulos was seen as a relief by European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker (10).

Timeline.Text: President Mahinda Rajapaksa signs a proclamation declaring his intention to hold a presidential election.
The ruling coalition party in Greece announces a snap presidential election to be held on December 17.
In the first round of voting, Parliament fails to elect a new Greek president.
A Greek lawmaker alleges a bribery attempt during the presidential vote.
Parliament fails to elect a new Greek president in the second round of voting.
Uncertainty hangs over Greece's bailout program as anti-austerity party leads in polls.
Municipal and regional elections are held in Greece, marking the first electoral test since the 2012 twin earthquake elections.
Greece has the worst unemployment rate in the European Union.
Former conservative lawmaker Prokopis Pavlopoulos is elected as the new president of Greece.

Overview.Summary: In 2014 and 2015, Greece held a presidential election that resulted in a snap election (1,2,4,10). The government candidate, Prokopis Pavlopoulos, was ultimately elected as the next president (2,8). The election caused a political crisis and had a significant impact on the markets (3,4,9). The first round of voting took place on December 30, 2014 (1) and the second round on December 24, 2014 (7). The final result was announced on February 23, 2015 (8).

Timeline.Text: The possibility of a snap election in Greece becomes more likely after the government fails to win the first round of the presidential vote.
The failure to elect a new president means that Greece will likely face a snap election.
The Greek parliament announces that a snap election will be held on January 25th.
The upcoming general election in Greece is scheduled for 25th January.
Live coverage of the Greek general election is provided as the results come in.
Prokopis Pavlopoulos is elected as the next president of Greece.
Prokopis Pavlopoulos, the candidate of the government, is elected as the next president of Greece.

Overview.Summary: The 2014-2015 Greek presidential election (9, 10) was a political gamble by Prime Minister Antonis Samaras (9). The election was held over three rounds, with the final vote on December 29 (1, 5, 6). If a candidate does not receive 180 votes, national elections will be held (6, 7). The president of Greece is elected by the 300 members of the Hellenic Parliament (3, 4). In the first or second round, the candidate must gain 200 out of 300 votes (9). The outgoing Head of State Carolos Papoulias could not stand for re-election (6). The election has raised doubts about the country's bailout plans (8).

Timeline.Text: The Greek parliament prepares for a snap presidential election, with the first or second round requiring 200 votes.
The Greek Prime Minister Antonis Samaras takes a political gamble by calling for a presidential election three months ahead of schedule.
The Greek presidential election begins, with three rounds of voting and a two thirds majority needed for a candidate to be elected.
The third and final round of voting is held in the Greek parliament to elect a new president, with failure leading to national elections.
The Greek parliament rejects a presidential candidate, forcing a snap election and risking a bailout.
The outgoing Head of State Carolos Papoulias, who is ending his second mandate, cannot stand again in the upcoming presidential election.
The Greek presidential election takes place, with the new president requiring 180 votes to be voted in by parliament.

Overview.Summary: The 2014-2015 Greek presidential election was a highly contentious event that sparked concerns among international creditors (13, 18). The first round of voting took place on December 17, 2014 (13, 20) and was accelerated in order to ease political uncertainty (13). The election was ultimately rejected, forcing snap elections and risking a bailout (3, 4). The election was seen as a big slap in the face to Europe and a potential domino effect across the continent (19). It was also seen as a potential showdown for the country in 2015 (18).

Timeline.Text: The first round of voting for the Greek presidential election takes place, with candidate Stavros Dimas receiving 160 votes.
The Greek parliament fails to elect a president of the Republic, forcing snap elections to be organized on January 25, 2015.
The Republican National Committee releases the debate schedule for the 2016 presidential election.
After the Greek presidential election, Italy must also appoint a new President of the Republic.
The Greek election results are seen as a 'big slap in the face' to Europe.
The GOP candidates for the presidential election are rated using a points system.
Conservative candidate Prokopis Pavlopoulos is elected as the new President of Greece with a wide majority.
Uruguay's president Jose Mujica steps down, known for his humble lifestyle.
The Greek parliament rejects the first round of voting for the presidential election, setting the stage for snap elections.
The Greek presidential election is covered by Greek Web TV Live, with a new anchor making a controversial statement.
